40rahxE_cow,Russia-Ukraine War: Putin Visits Kursk For The First Time After Ukrainian Troop Withdrawal
column2: GRAVITAS,"Russian President Vladimir Putin visited the Kursk region for the first time since Russian forces pushed out Ukrainian troops last month. He acknowledged the continued challenges in the border area and announced extended financial support for affected residents. Meanwhile, drone footage released by Russia shows a missile strike on a Ukrainian training camp in Sumy, reportedly killing six, though Moscow claims much higher casualties. Amid the escalation, Ukrainian President Zelensky has signaled readiness to meet Putin directly, following calls with U.S. President Trump, though no major progress has been made toward a ceasefire.

X: https://twitter.com/ForcesNews",BFBS Forces News,2025-05-21T17:01:04Z,Forces News;Forces TV;British Armed Forces;British;Forces;military;serving;military personnel;Ministry of Defence;British defence;British military;BFBS;BFBS Forces News;Simon Newton;Nato;NATO;Kursk;Vladimir Putin;Finland;Sweden;Murmansk;Olenya;Kamenka;Alakurtti;Petrozavadsk,39668,1312,319,UgzS_C1tQbdwHVt8XSd4AaABAg,@glacieractivity,"Not particular stressful for either the Finnish or the Norwegians at the moment. They have a full Division plus 2 extra brigades parked in walking distance from Norway (plus 14th Army and lots and lots of naval and marine units in Murmansk per usual). They have a brigade dispatched to the central Finnish border, and around St Petersburg/the southern Finish border, everything is equally normal with the 6th Army. They are all reduced and thus smaller than during a happy spring day in 2019. Both Norway, Sweden and Finland is lifting off fighter jets to say hi to Russian fighters and bombers on a weekly basis.
What is dramatic for British media does not pop up in media over here as it is daily life.

Sure, there is a 5-year perspective on things, but that has always been daily life for more or less a century for everyone over here. Calm down. We will give a heads-up if we get worried. With lessons from Ukraine when Russia spent months to gather troops with absolutely no intention of attacking anyone (hehe) that heads up will come with months of time to prepare for our allies and NATO response forces.

Russia setting up a few tent camps around us is hardly nothing to get an adrenaline rush from. Fact is that Russia has built these tent camps on and off for training purposes (and sometimes just as ""Potemkin cities"" for internal propaganda or to see if we pay attention) for decades.

By 2030, we should obviously be ready to flex enough to make even less than rational Russian leaders to think ""no, we probably should not pretend to not be aggressive lying Russian bi*hes per normal"" - thus that work is ongoing with increasing speed all over the place. But again - totally without short term raised pulse rates.",3,2025-05-21T18:12:58Z

lW4h7aXNNR8,Russia reactivates Cold War bases - right on Nato's border,"Almost a million Russian personnel are estimated to have been killed, captured or wounded fighting in Ukraine and Kursk.
But despite those staggering losses, Russian president Vladimir Putin is still likely to have a bigger military when this conflict ends than when it began.
And there are indications that Moscow is already preparing its post-war posture, with signs that Russia is beefing up its military presence along its western border.

A British general and his American counterpart are sharing a bottle of Bordeaux. The Cold War hums quietly in the background.
‚ÄúImagine a fairy shows up and offers you one wish ‚Äî any strategic gain for the West. What would you choose?‚Äù
The Brit thinks for a moment.
‚ÄúI‚Äôd wish for the Russians and the Ukrainians to wipe each other out. No need for us to get involved.‚Äù
The Brit nods slowly, then says with a faint smirk:
‚ÄúBe reasonable, old chap. Fairies don‚Äôt grant absurd wishes.‚Äù
They both chuckle ‚Äî and the bottle is nearly empty.
